item.title: Record GCSE results after second year of no exams
item.description: Record high GCSE grades in a second year of exams disrupted by the pandemic.

item.title: UK economy rebounds as Covid restrictions ease
item.description: Retail, restaurants and hotels show strong growth between April and June but data misses forecasts.

item.title: Covid: Higher GCSE results predicted and UK economy grows
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday morning.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban take 10th provincial capital as Ghazni falls
item.description: The fall of Ghazni, south-west of Kabul, brings the militants closer to the Afghan capital.

item.title: Afghanistan war: Do the Taliban want to conquer or compromise?
item.description: The BBC speaks to two high profile figures in its chain of command who have very different messages.

item.title: Tributes to dad stabbed after confronting youths
item.description: James Markham, 45, was killed after confronting a group of youths outside his home.

item.title: New Zealand borders to remain closed for rest of the year
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said her priority was vaccinating the population by the end of 2021.

item.title: Australian capital Canberra goes into snap lockdown
item.description: The one-week lockdown comes after Canberra recorded its first case of Covid-19 for more than a year.

item.title: Tui's European bookings jump on pent-up demand
item.description: But UK bookings lag behind amid shifting Covid travel restrictions, the travel firm says.

item.title: Boohoo boss: 'We're not a throwaway fashion brand'
item.description: The boss of fast fashion retailer Boohoo tells the BBC it is committed to being more sustainable.

item.title: Tourist helicopter crashes into Russian lake
item.description: Eight people survived after a helicopter with 16 people crashed in the Far East region, reports say.

item.title: Cryptocurrency heist hacker returns $260m in funds
item.description: The hacker behind the $600m Poly Network cryptocurrency heist has posted a Q&A on the blockchain.

item.title: Electric cars: Do ministers put their motor where their mouth is?
item.description: Politicians are keen for us to live greener lives, but how many have taken the electric car plunge?

item.title: The Papers: 'Spy sold secrets' and 'no way back for Andrew'
item.description: Thursday's papers report fears that a spy at the British embassy in Berlin sold data to Russia.

item.title: The shopkeeper saving his island from wildfires
item.description: Spyros isn't a firefighter, but when his home was threatened with wildfires, he decided to take action.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Meet Tokyo's youngest Olympic champion
item.description: Japan's Momiji Nishiya won the first women’s street skateboarding gold in the sport's Olympic debut.

item.title: Charles and Diana's wedding cake slice sells for £1,850
item.description: The 40-year-old slice of wedding cake was bought by a buyer from Leeds.

item.title: Sheffield girlfriend gives partner 'gift of life' kidney donation
item.description: Eddie Huntley has a rare disease and was on dialysis three times a week before the transplant.

item.title: Afghanistan war: Taliban back brutal rule as they strike for power
item.description: Afghanistan's ex-rulers still back brutal punishments, the BBC finds as it goes behind Taliban lines.

item.title: How we can all get more high-quality sleep
item.description: The pandemic has led to a sharp increase in insomnia, but some firms are now helping their staff.

item.title: How North American cities are bracing for more heatwaves
item.description: Local governments are getting creative when it comes to tackling frequent and extreme heat.

item.title: Afghanistan: The people fleeing the north for safety in Kabul
item.description: The Taliban has taken new territories in the north, forcing thousands out of their homes.

item.title: Sweet Anita: Tourette's queen of Twitch
item.description: Anita broadcasts to thousands every week, playing games whilst talking Tourette's and mental health.

item.title: Lily Allen on making her West End debut in 2:22 - A Ghost Story
item.description: The singer is temporarily pausing her successful music career to star in a brand new play 2:22.

item.title: Wildfires: How are they linked to climate change?
item.description: A series of major wildfires across the world has hit the headlines - how do they compare to previous years?

item.title: National anthem: Should Wales' teams sing God Save the Queen?
item.description: Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau has been sung before Wales rugby internationals for 116 years.

item.title: Chelsea champions? Or Man City to defend crown? Shearer & BBC pundit team predict Premier League title race
item.description: We ask 20 BBC pundits to predict who will win the Premier League title, who will finish in the top four, and who might break into the top six.

item.title: England's Broad out of India series - Anderson a doubt for second Test
item.description: Stuart Broad will miss the remainder of England's series against India because of a calf tear and James Anderson is a doubt for the second Test.

item.title: Haye to return to the ring to fight 'overconfident billionaire buddy' Fournier
item.description: Former heavyweight and cruiserweight champion David Haye returning to the ring in September to face Joe Fournier.

item.title: Kepa goes from shootout villain to Super Cup hero
item.description: Kepa Arrizabalaga's time at Chelsea has been defined by an incident involving a substitution with penalties looming - and now another, but in much happier circumstances.

item.title: Konta to face Gauff in last 16 after beating third seed Svitolina at Canadian Open
item.description: British number one Johanna Konta fights back from a set down to defeat third seed Elina Svitolina and reach the Canadian Open third round.

item.title: GCSE results 2021: How were grades decided?
item.description: Teachers have decided their pupils' grades after Covid cancelled exams for a second year.

item.title: GCSEs 2021: The 9-1 grading system explained
item.description: Teenagers will receive their GCSE results on 12 August.

item.title: Exams 2021: 'Will they take our Covid grades seriously?'
item.description: It's been a stressful few months for the thousands of young people waiting for their exam results.

item.title: A-level results: Students have been treated fairly - watchdog
item.description: The head of the exams regulator defends the system for deciding grades ahead of A-level and GCSE results day.

item.title: UK holidays: What are the rules?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The government has announced that 16 and 17-year-olds will receive the Covid vaccine.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.
